course.subject: COMP
course.name: Multimedia Computing
course.description: Color theory; digital audio, image and video fundamentals, representation, and processing; digital multimedia applications and programming.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H

reviews.author: smallpotato tom
reviews.title: Nice lecturer and acceptable grading
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about "multimedia" - digitization, MIDI, audio, image and video. Mainly teach you the concepts of them and how to code (using web programming) to produce or process these multimedia elements. Quite interesting.

(* is the most difficult part I think)

-- Fundamental Part --
0. Introduction
1. Sampling
2. Quantization

-- Audio Part --
3. Introduction to MIDI
4. More on MIDI
5. Basic Digital Audio Concepts
6. Basic Waveform Generation
7. Frequency Domain
8. Additive Synthesis
9. Frequency Modulation*
10. Post-Processing Effects
11. Echo and Reverberation
12. The Karplus-Strong Algorithm
13. MIDI and Music Synthesis

-- Image Part --
14. Image and Colour
15. HTML Canvas
16. Monadic Image Processing
17. Image Dithering*
18. Histograms
19. Blur
20. Edge and Sharpen*
21. Kuwahara Filter

-- Video Part --
22. Basic Video Processing
23. Video Motion Tracking
24. Shaking Camera Removal
25. Chroma Key Effect*

-- Compression Part --
26. Lossless Audio Compression*
27. Lossy Audio Compression*
28. Lossless Audio Compression*
29. Lossy Audio Compression*
30. Video Compression
reviews.comment_teaching: Gibson is really a nice lecturer. I never feel sleepy when attending his classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
1. Lab work - 30% (Best 6 out of 8 labs)
2. Mini group project - 20%
3. Participation - 10%
(Lecture video quizzes + Pop quizzes)
4. Online Final Exam - 40%

I got full marks in lab and participation, slightly above mean in the project and slightly below mean in the final exam (a few scores). Got a B.

It's acceptable actually.
reviews.comment_workload:
In this semester, we had lessons online.

The lectures in a week were divided into two part. The first lecture was a video lecture that covers 2 to 3 topics each time. Gibson recorded videos and uploaded to the official site. We had to watch these videos and then answer some questions on Canvas (to gain participation scores). The second lecture was an activity lecture. Gibson wouldn't teach new things but would have pop quizzes during lessons. Again we had to answer the questions on Canvas to gain the participation scores.

8 labs, 1 lab for MIDI, 3 labs for audio, 3 labs for image and 1 lab for video. Lab attendance was not necessary. All lab work was programming. The necessary tools for me were just Chrome and VS Code. Not hard.

The project was done in group. Gibson provided a list of topics (about MIDI, audio, image and video). We needed to choose 1 from them and then built it.

The final online exam was open-book but quite hard.

reviews.author: Toxick
reviews.title: Easy for those who like web development
reviews.comment_content: The course revolves around MIDI, Audio, Image and Video Processing. You have to watch David's MOOC course the basics of HTML, CSS, JavaScript and jQuery at first. You need basic web programming knowledge to get through the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
David will walk you through the concepts on the whiteboard rather than relying on the PPTs. He's a funny instructor. He's a rare kind of instructor in UST I would say. He really doesn't like people disturbing him while he's teaching.

For the labs, it's pretty straight-forward. You just have to follow what the TA codes and you would have completed 80% of the tasks.
reviews.comment_grading:
40% Labs
15% Midterm
45% Final

Labs are easy. You can get full marks by following all the pseudo code and instructions. The only difficulty would be the Specialization project. You have to pick 1 of the lab project and propose some extra functions to add on to it. You will get some ideas in class discussion.

Both exams are open-book. They mostly consist short answer and MC questions. You would only have less than an hour for the midterm. For the finals, you would have some multimedia questions like listen to a music clip.

I got a B- at the end.
I scored an average of 98% of the labs. And full marks on the specialization project. Midterm Final below 1SD. I thought the exams would screw me up but they didn't. LOL. The grading is awesome.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you have learnt web development before, the labs would be easy. You can finish them within a day. It's the easiest 4000-level course you will ever see.

For exams, David even let us vote on what topics we would like to be tested. Our class crossed out all the video processing topics. So you can study even less!

Labs were all either full marks or just slightly below, everyone should be getting close to full marks.

Mini project was slightly below mean.

A few assignments, a small project, midterm, and a final exam.

They aren't that hard as long as you understand what was taught in class and haven't forgotten your programming from comp2011.

Gibson teaches well so I learned the stuff pretty well, so it didn't feel that hard for me.

reviews.author: FeiFei
reviews.title: Good (online) course with good instructor
reviews.comment_content:
This is a course to teach you how to process audio, image and video in a digital way. You also need a few skills on JavaScript and HTML (not that demanding like COMP4021). Dave's MOOC notes and videos will be provided for self-studying so you don't actually need to take COMP4021 as well. As a 4000-level course, this is definitely academically easier than others.

The course contents can be divided into mainly 5(/6?) parts:
0. Basics
- HTML and JavaScript
- Multimedia Representation - Sampling and Quantization

1. MIDI
- MIDI features and controls

2. Audio
- Basic Waveform Generation and Frequency Domain
- Sound Generations (Additive Synthesis/Frequency Modulation)
- Post-processing effects (Reversal/Amplitude control/Tremolo/etc.)
- Echo and Reverberation
- Karplus-Strong Algorithm
- MIDI and Music synthesis

3. Images
- Colors (RGB/CMYK/HSV)
- Monadic image processing (Negation/Grayscale/etc.)
- Image Dithering
- Histogram processing
- Local operations (Blur/Edge/Sharpening)
- Kuwahara Filter

4. Video
- Video processing (Reverse/Transitions/Motion blur)
- Motion Tracking and Shaking Camera Removal
- Chroma Key Effect (something like green screen)

5. Compression
- Lossless/Lossy Audio compression
- Lossless/Lossy Image compression
- (Lossy) Video compression

For the Labs, each part will have a set of lab(s).
The first Lab 0 is self-studying lab for HTML and JavaScript with nothing to do and submit.
Lab 1 is about MIDI, which requires to make a MIDI keyboards.
Lab 2, 3, 4 are about Audio which are done on the same materials. Lab 2 is basic audio generation, Lab 3 adds post-processing effects and sound generation, and Lab 4 adds more post-processing effects and Karplus-Strong Algorithm.
Lab 5, 6, 7 are about Image which are also done on the same materials. Lab 5 is about basic processing and comic color, Lab 6 adds dithering features and histogram handling, while Lab 7 adds filtering (e.g. blur).
Lab 8 is about Video, which needs us to implement certain processing effects.

There are also a mini group project to do, which is an extension to the Lab work. You can choose 1 of the 4 Labs to work with, and various features for each topic could be chosen. Some projects requires only 2 people, while others need 3 people.

Overall, the contents are very ordered and well-organized, so that you won't get lost when you are learning or reviewing. The contents are not very challenging, yet interesting to learn.
While doing the lab works, you would also find it funny and relaxing to apply the effects and see the results. I would say this course is not boring at all!
reviews.comment_teaching:
[Warning: Spring 2020 is conducted in online lecture mode, so some of the reviews might not be applicable afterwards]

Gibson is quite enthusiastic at teaching, right? You should know his style of teaching if you have taken 1000-level course from him. 喼神喎。

Originally we had Mon and Wed lectures. However, this semester the course is switched to blended learning mode.

On weekend the materials and (pre-recorded) lecture videos of next week will be released. There are video questions to answer, in which you need to watch lecture videos to answer, because sometimes Gibson just asked some silly questions which are related to things only appear in the video.
Each question is worth 1 point of that week. Sometimes the videos could be as long as 1 hour. This is tiring but the explanations are very clear.

There will be no Lecture on Monday, and Wednesday lecture becomes activity lecture. Gibson will make some review, and ask pop quizzes related to materials that week.
These questions would be similar to the materials, or somehow extensions on the contents. Each pop quiz question is worth 2 points, while survey (don't care about correctness) is 1 point.

Labs are using pre-recorded video (also by Gibson) and lab page. Most of the steps are easy to follow and implement, while some harder parts require you to think and code by yourself.

Actually Gibson did a great job to explain contents. The flow is fluent and clear. Of course the notes are very clean and easy to follow, which is the same as those 1000-level courses. You should take it if you want a high-quality teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
[Warning: Spring 2020 is conducted in online lecture mode, so some of the reviews might not be applicable afterwards]

The grading are quite lenient as previous.

Grading scheme:
Labs: 30% (Best 6 out of 8)
- Nearly everyone is full

Mini projects: 20%
- 5% description
- 5% video (~5 mins explaining works and codes)
- 5% completeness
- 5% complexity
Mean: 17.89
SD: 1.95
Max: 20

Participation: 10%
- Each week: 10 points maximum
  - Video questions and Survey: 1 point
  - Pop quiz question: 2 points
- 10 best week will be counted

Final: 40% (separated into 2 parts, 11 questions, 50 marks and 75 minutes each)
- Part 1: Image and Video
- Part 2: MIDI and Audio
- Open notes, Google, devices, … Just no communications
Mean: 63.6
SD: 16.6
Max: 94

My grade:
Labs: Full (30%)
Project: 18.5/20
Participation: Full (10%)
Final: 41+42 = 83/100 = 33.2% (~1.17 SD above mean)

Total: 91.7% (A)

I think the course grade is good, where you can get A/A- if you are around 1 SD above mean. Grade saver course (hopefully always true :p).
reviews.comment_workload:
[Warning: Spring 2020 is conducted in online lecture mode, so some of the reviews might not be applicable afterwards]

The workload is not that tedious, especially as a 4000-level course. This should be one of the lowest workload course that you take in the semester.

The main workload comes from watching lecture videos, doing labs and course project. You can even avoid the videos if you are in normal teaching mode!

The labs could be completed within few hours, with tons of instructions to follow. Just spare some more time for struggling, debugging and testing to achieve perfect score.

The workload for project would be of similar magnitude or scale as a set of labs. I took few days (few hours per day) to complete it with my groupmate, while also doing another project from COMP4021.
The process includes figuring out the algorithm, implementation, debugging and recording the video. You just need to take little time out from your busy works, and hope there is no free-rider(s) occurred.

reviews.comment_content:
Using web to handle multimedia including audio, music, image and video.

Audio includes making a piano keyboard and a musical whiteboard with MIDI.

Music includes making sound waves with time domain method and additive synthesis method, and sound effects such as echo, tremolo and FM.

Image includes applying effects like negate, ripple, threshold and posterization to the image and making a kernel operation for image blur, edge and sharpen.

Video includes applying effects like motion blur, earthquake and cross fade to the video.

reviews.author: Abishek
reviews.title: Interesting Course but boring Assignments
reviews.comment_content:
I found the content of the course to be very engaging, the course is split into three distinct parts.

1) Image processing : How to manipulate jpg,png and other image formats, how to use VB to import and modify such images and the theory of image coding ie color representation,filtering algorithms,background removal,insertion etc.

2) Audio Processing: How to use MIDI with VB to manipulate different aspects of sound like pitch, duration and volume. Learn how an echo works as well as tremolo,pitch trimming and magnification and other things in this area.

3) Video Processing: Really combines part 1 and 2 together, mainly focussing on effecient ways to apply image or sound processing techniques to multiple frames. Also includes how to detect moving frames and correct them as well as how to select certain important frames based on how much changes happens.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is fairly good, as I did it in the summer the pace of the classes were quite fast, which I personally like, and the powerpoint slides given cover almost all the material. However, the professor sometimes talks a little bit extra in one area if interested and you should always write that stuff down, because it might partially appear in a question in the exam.

One slight downside is that the structure is kept very basic. It is almost exclusively the professor talking to students using the powerpoints. There is no interaction in the form of questions or quizzes, which I personally like.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was extremely fair, although having done it in the summer might bias the results. A range was given to about 10 people in a class of 30 odd, so good chance of doing well, and as its mainly projects if you score 100 on them all you are really set for a good overall grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was fairly standard for a COMP course, having to do 3 assignments that are not too intense in terms of planning, most of the material was given in the lab notes, we only had to add maybe 10% extra to finish the assignments.

reviews.author: Threch
reviews.comment_content:
Very fruitful contents in multimedia aspects including audio, image and video.

1. Audio
- Sampling, Quantization
- MIDI
- Waveform Generation (Time-domain, additive synthesis, Frequency Modulation)
- Frequency Domain
- Post-Processing effects
- Echo and Reverberation
- Karplus-Strong Algorithm

2. Image
- Monadic Image Processing (Negation, Grayscale, Brightness/Contrast, Posterization, Thresholding)
- Dithering
- Histogram
- Blur, Edge, Sharpen, Kuwahara Filter

3. Video
- Video Motion Tracking, Stabilization
- Chroma Key Effect

4. Compression
- Lossless Audio/ Image Compression
- Lossy Audio/Image Compression
- Video Compression

Lab consists of Javascript and HTML knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gibson is a very good lecturer and he will explains the contents in detail, step by step and you can easily understand them.

During the blended learning mode, the lecture is used to do some Pop Quiz which is question related to the lecture video content, which are good to understand the concepts behind.

Every week Gibson will release the lecture video and we have few days to finish the videos and do the lecture quiz (which are easy) on canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Gibson is lenient in grading. Getting a nearly above mean score in final exam still worth for a B grade :D

Grading scheme:
10% Participation (Canvas Pop quiz and lecture video quiz)
30% Lab (Easy as Gibson will give you lab video to explain what you need to do in the code. Not difficult at all)
20% Mini Project (2-3 people in a group)
40% Final Exam

You can expect that participation and lab will have very high mean score.
For the mean of mini project is around 17.5/20
For the mean of final exam is around 59/100
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly workload is just the lecture video and the lab. You can spend 1-2 hrs to finish the lecture video and 1 hr for the lab, which is not a high workload.

Major workload comes from the mini project. You need to choose a predefined topic from Gibson (or you can self-declare your topic to Gibson for approval which is okay) and finish it in a group of 2-3. The project is basically based on the previous lab you have done. Your job is to add some features to it which are also related to lecture contents. The project requires Javascript coding so you may need to learn a bit of it before starting the project.

Highly recommended for those who are interested in Multimedia.
